results.content:
I am about close to 50% done and there are several glaring issues I think other potential students should consider before buying this course. In fact the instructor changed the title to year 2020, but in fact a lot of the content is old and no longer application (see few other 1 star reviews for detail):
- The instructor, while very knowledgeable, has a very strong accept, certain words and pronunciations are very bad and really distracts me from the lectures. Those considering buying, check out the preview videos, listen to his voice and accept, and see if this is something that you can endure for the entirely of the lesson.
- The visual design of the projects are pretty bad, to say the least. Sure, this is not a design course, but I do expect the materials and assets to be given some thought and creativity, but for the first half, it just HTML elements with really bad color or just lazy implementation like a regular div with assets (images, text, etc) put into them.
- The instructor even use table in the HTML, table is not recommended, read this article here (https://www.lifewire.com/dont-use-tables-for-layout-3468941)
I cant believe this is actually being taught in a paid course
- The local test environment should use it's own small section. For example in section 8 about optimizing for mobile, one part about android optimizing is about the the meta theme-color, but this doesnt work locally (it works in his video, but I cant recreate it). I further dig into this issue, because it's due to invalid certificate error (HTTPS). See stackoverflow for detail here (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33701823/chrome-mobile-color-bar-theme-color-meta-tag-not-working). If you want to able to see this part working locally, u need to install additional tools like mkcert (https://dev.to/rhymes/really-easy-way-to-use-https-on-localhost-341m). 

I am only half way in, with all of the above issues combined, I cant recommended this course without the instructor doing some clean up on his end to clarify and improve his teaching material.

Good luck everyone, but this course will go straight into my archive and never see the light again until further notice.

results.content:
This course is strangely structured, since it jumps from html and css basic stuff straight to web apis, which has pretty advanced javascript. Don't expect to learn any javascript here, you'll have just 30 minutes of javascript introduction before going to web apis, which is advanced js, and one day is not enough to learn js. It takes months to learn js, not minutes. And he is using ES5, which is pretty outdated. Some of the web apis are outdated also and don't work anymore.
The teacher should update the code of the course to ES6+. He keeps updating the year in the name of the course, though he does not update the code at all.
I gave 4 stars because I saw in this course interesting things about web apis that I didn't see on other courses, so this made it worthy to me.

results.content:
I've been coding for over a decade, but keeping up-to-date with available APIs and techniques isn't easy. This course did an excellent job at providing an overview of the currently available technologies and current levels of support.

I would have given it 5 stars, but there is some (very little) outdated information, namely that iOS Safari does now support several features related to Service Workers. I also wish he had spent more time building the projects so novice coders could get used to building full applications. For someone like me who's been doing this a while, it was fine, but for someone who's just getting started I think more information on how to actually build the various projects involved would be beneficial. Of course, YMMV based on your own level of experience and comfort with the material.

results.content: Just wow!  This is one of my favourite courses that I've taken on udemy so far.  The real world projects are fantastic.   I'm constantly surprised at all the new tidbits of information Max shares with his students.  I work full-time in a web development role, and usually spend my evenings watching web development courses, yet still Max was able to surprise me with stuff that I didn't know.  I'm exciting to put some of what I've learned into practice.  The one  thing to be aware of is that I wouldn't consider this a beginner course.  You should have some prior knowledge and  experience with HTML, CSS, and Javascript to be able to keep up with the pace of the course.

results.content: Well, I'll tell why I gave 1 star only. it's not because the course is useless. The course contents are very much useful. In terms of technology and explanation perspective, Max has done a great job. But, the contents are super old. For example, access the device sensors not allowed from iOS 13. We have to use "requestPermission" which is no one knows if they simply follow these lectures. I would strongly request to Max update the contents accordingly because the course is very good for those who are looking for the latest technologies. But we cannot say the latest if they are not working.
